text:
Elizabeth Pankratz (she/her) ‚ú®
Hi! I‚Äôm a PhD student at the University of Edinburgh‚Äôs Centre for Language Evolution where I‚Äôm supervised by Prof.¬†Jennifer Culbertson and Prof.¬†Simon Kirby.
My CV (PDF)

Research
In my PhD, I use behavioural experiments and computational models to study

how people segment linguistic material (see Pankratz et al., 2024!),
how they learn rules from it,
how they generalise those rules to novel instances,

and how those processes might shape language.


Statistics
I‚Äôm trained in both Bayesian and frequentist statistics, and I‚Äôm very happy to be contacted for stats/methods consulting for your project.
LEL students at Edinburgh can book one-on-one help sessions with me (book here under ‚ÄúDiss stats‚Äù).


Contact
e.c.pankratz@sms.ed.ac.uk

title: Doctors hate this one weird synthesis matrix trick
text:
Not a lot of what I did in the first year of my PhD was a great use of time‚Ä¶ but I did create a darn good setup for managing my literature that‚Äôs paying off years later.
The key idea: use Google Forms to build a synthesis matrix.

title: Doctors hate this one weird synthesis matrix trick
text:
The synthesis matrix
Imagine a spreadsheet in which every row is a book or paper you‚Äôve read, and every column is a topic that‚Äôs important for your research. If a source says something interesting about a topic, you jot down in that column a quick note or a nice quotation.
Then when the time comes to write a paper about ‚Äúwordhood cues‚Äù, say (yknow, just hypothetically), you can revisit the notes you‚Äôve left in the ‚Äúwordhood cues‚Äù column to see everything folks have said on the topic.
Here‚Äôs an excerpt of mine:
¬†



BibTeX Key
Keywords
Main idea
Wordhood cues




DixonAikhenvald2002a (link)
wordhood, typology
Separately define both ‚Äúgrammatical words‚Äù and ‚Äúphonological words‚Äù
No single phon. criterion for every language. A few gram. criteria that can work for every language.


Haspelmath2011 (link)
wordhood, typology
No criteria for wordhood are reliable cross-linguistically
Discusses applicability of ten (grammatical) criteria


Wray2015 (link)
wordhood, literacy
Intuitions about wordhood are based on orthography and on the prototype of word as concrete noun
Word mainly as orthographic unit



¬†
The synthesis matrix quickly became my favourite way to manage my PhD literature.

It preserves ideas from a paper you‚Äôre reading now but may not actually cite for another three years.
It simplifies writing lit reviews based around ideas (like ‚ÄúCats are good (Author A, Author B)‚Äù) instead of based around authors (‚ÄúAuthor A says cats are good. Author B agrees‚ÄùÔ∏è).
It makes collaborating on lit reviews a breeze: your colleague can enter notes from a source they‚Äôve read, and then you‚Äôve got access to the key points too.

The problem: Entering text straight into a spreadsheet can be such a pain.

title: Doctors hate this one weird synthesis matrix trick
text:
Enter: Google Forms
With Google Forms (or Microsoft Forms, or probably many others‚Äîpick your poison), you can create a ‚Äúsurvey‚Äù that contains a bunch of text fields, each corresponding to a piece of information that you want to record.





Then once you submit this form, the text you entered in each field will be saved as a new row in a spreadsheet.





If you decide after creating the form that you want to start taking notes on a new topic, then it‚Äôs as easy as editing the form to add a new question. A new column will automatically be added into the spreadsheet.

title: Doctors hate this one weird synthesis matrix trick
text:
What to record?
For each source, I record:

BibTeX key
Topics/keywords
Main idea
Data/evidence/method used (e.g., ‚Äúexperiment‚Äù, ‚Äúreview paper‚Äù, ‚Äúnarrative argumentation‚Äù)
Overall impression (e.g., ‚Äúhas great lit review‚Äù, ‚Äúhard to follow‚Äù)
Followup lit (any papers that are mentioned that I should go read)
Followup ideas (questions/ideas that this source raises)

Then I also have many optional questions about the different research topics that I‚Äôm interested in, for example:

Wordhood cues
Rule generalisation
Emergence of compositional structure

Of course not every source weighs in on every topic. I just take notes under the topics that are relevant.

This literature management method has really helped me, and I hope it can help somebody else out there! Happy synthesising üòä

title: Handmade derby boots 1: Drafting the pattern
text:
In a series of posts, I‚Äôm going to share my process for crafting a pair of handsewn, hand-welted leather derby boots.
I‚Äôm absolutely not a shoemaking expert. I‚Äôm fully self-taught, and my process is a weird melange of professional bespoke techniques and idiosyncratic hacks. But I‚Äôve been wearing the first pair of hand-welted derby boots I made every day for nearly a year, and they‚Äôre holding up really well. So whatever I‚Äôm doing is good enough for me!
To create my new derby boot pattern, I‚Äôm mostly following instructions from the book Handcraft Your Own Shoes and Boots by Neda Hussain. I‚Äôve noted other useful references and sources for shoemaking materials at the bottom of the post.

title: Handmade derby boots 1: Drafting the pattern
text:
The process

Cover the last (that is, the foot form) in masking tape and mark essential points.
Cut the tape off the last and stick each side flat onto paper to create the inside and outside forms.
Average out any wobbly bits to create the mean form.
Add on design lines to create the standard form.
Using the standard form, create pattern pieces.


1. Taping the last
Overall, what I‚Äôm doing here is moving from the 3D shape of a last down to a 2D representation. Covering the last in masking tape, then cutting the tape off and sticking it down flat onto some card, gives me a decent approximation of the curves and contours of the foot.







These are my lasts! Only one needs to be taped up if they‚Äôre approximately the same shape. I‚Äôve augmented them with cork where my feet are wider and rasped and sanded them down where my feet are smaller.









One last covered in masking tape. I‚Äôve marked a line down the centre of the foot (and out of view, another black line marks the centre of the heel).


I marked the centre lines down the front and heel, as well as the ‚Äúvamp point‚Äù: the widest point of the last measured from the ball of the foot across to the pinky knuckle. This is also the point where the ‚Äúquarters‚Äù end and the ‚Äúvamp‚Äù begins. The ‚Äúquarters‚Äù are the pieces on each side of the foot and ankle that meet the strap at the centre back and hold all the eyelets for the laces on either side of the front. The ‚Äúvamp‚Äù is the piece that joins the toe cap in the front, curves around the sides of the foot to lie below the quarters, and extends upwards between the quarters to make the tongue.


2. Getting the inside and outside forms
I also marked the ‚Äúcounter point‚Äù CP on the heel, sliced the tape along those two centre lines, and stuck each half down onto card and cut them out.







The tape has been peeled off of the last and stuck down onto card. The VP (‚Äúvamp point‚Äù) and CP (‚Äúcounter point‚Äù) have been marked on tthe instep and heel respectively.


Getting the tape approximately flat is good enough for most of the foot‚Äîthose wrinkles aren‚Äôt the end of the world. But small slices around the outside edge are essential to help the toe lie down smoothly.


3. Finding the mean form
The mean form is so called because it‚Äôs the mean, i.e., average, of the inside and outside forms.







From the last to the mean form: a 2D representation of its shape!


I overlaid the inside and outside forms on another piece of card and traced around each of them. Then I marked the line that falls in between each of those outlines and cut along it (except for the bottom front of the foot‚Äîthere I kept the full width of the outside form).
I only need to do all this once. Now that I have the mean form, I can use it as the basis for every pair of shoes I design for this last from now on.


4. Creating the standard form
Here‚Äôs where things get design-specific and the shape of the derby boot starts to emerge!
This step involves tracing the mean form onto another piece of paper, marking a bunch of points in particular locations, and drawing a bunch of lines between them at specific angles and with specific lengths. I leaned heavily on the Hussain book here!







The standard form is like the first mock-up of the shoe pattern. It‚Äôs the basis for making all the individual pattern pieces.


One place I diverged from the Hussain book: that book is written for making shoes using the stitch-down construction (i.e., the upper of the shoe is sewn directly onto the midsole), a construction that‚Äôs easier to sew but a lot harder to resole. I‚Äôm going to hand-welt my shoes instead (see this Shoegazing post on different construction methods). Hand-welting requires the lasting allowance around the bottom edge to be a lot more generous than stitch-down requires its seam allowance to be. I used 25 mm total.


5. Getting the pattern pieces
Finally, I followed the Hussain book to derive from the standard form the four pattern pieces I‚Äôll cut from my leather.







The four pattern pieces for my derby boots: heel counter with back strap (top left), toe cap (top right), quarters (bottom right), and vamp (bottom left).


For easier tracing, I glued the paper pieces onto card (sourced from a recycled folder, hence the funny ridges!).
That‚Äôs all for now :)

Where I get shoemaking supplies (in the UK)

I get my leather from Leather4Craft (get vegetable tanned, not chrome tanned, if you can!).
The Carreducker shop has a lot of great supplies, including pretty niche tools that are hard to find elsewhere.
My lasts are from I Can Make Shoes, but lasts can also be found more affordably on platforms like Etsy.
As a last (ha) resort: Amazon.
